The '''Medallion Shield''' is an annual [[rugby union]] competition involving schools affiliated to the [[Ulster Rugby|Ulster Branch]] of the [[Irish Rugby Football Union]]. The competition is open to all schools within [[Ulster]], but only schools from within [[Northern Ireland]] currently enter, with no entries from schools situated in the three Ulster counties within the [[Republic of Ireland]].
The competition has been contested continuously since its inception in 1910 and, in that time, fourteen different schools have secured at least a shared win of the shield. Teams entering the Medallion Shield are composed of boys that are under 15 years of age at the start of the school year. Entry in 2011-12 stood at 36 schools.
[[Methodist College Belfast]] is the most successful school with 37 wins (34 outright wins and 3 shared wins). The current holder is [[Sullivan Upper School]].
==Foundation and growth==
It was reported in 1909 that discussions had taken place between [[Belfast Royal Academy]], [[Campbell College]], [[Methodist College Belfast|Methodist College]] and [[Royal Belfast Academical Institution]] about setting up a [[Rugby Union|rugby]] junior competition for pupils with an age qualification given as under fifteen years of age on the 1 November.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Public Schools Competition|page=4|date=30 March 1909|newspaper=[[Belfast Newsletter]]}}</ref> The success of the [[Leinster Schools Junior Cup]] which had started that year had prompted these discussions. Henry McIntosh, the Headmaster of Methodist College and respected [[Rugby Union|rugby]] coach, was the main driving force behind the idea.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}}
In 1910 [[Methodist College Belfast|Methodist College]] and [[Royal Belfast Academical Institution]] proceeded with the competition and for the first five years only these two schools competed.<ref name=Shield1910 >{{cite news|title=Rugby - Schools Junior Match|page=4|date=16 March 1910|newspaper=Belfast Newsletter}}</ref> The third school to join was [[Royal School Dungannon]] in 1915.<ref>{{cite news|title=Public Schools - "Under Fifteen" Match|page=3|date=19 March 1915|newspaper=Belfast Newsletter}}</ref> [[Bangor Grammar School]] entered for the first time in 1916, with [[Ballymena Academy]] and [[Coleraine Academical Institution]] following in 1917.<ref>{{cite news|title=Final of the Under Fifteen (Medallion) Match|page=2|date=29 March 1917|newspaper=Belfast Newsletter}}</ref>
In 1977 the organising committee of [[Belfast Royal Academy]], [[Methodist College]], [[Royal Belfast Academical Institution]] and [[Royal School Dungannon]] ceded control of the competition to the Ulster Branch of the [[Irish Rugby Football Union]].{{citation needed|date=April 2011}}
==Trophy==
Initially without a trophy, a medal was presented to the winning captain at the conclusion of the second final in 1911.<ref name=Shield1911>{{cite news|title=Methodist College v R.A.Institution for boys under 15 years of age|page=4|date=24 March 1911|newspaper=Belfast Newsletter}}</ref> The original Medallion Shield was presented by the Governors of [[Methodist College Belfast|Methodist College]] with the medal mounted on the shield. When the original shield was filled with the names of winners, the Governors also provided a replacement shield. The original shield is on exhibit and can be viewed at the Methodist College Heritage Centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://methody.biznetservers.com/dsp_sub.cfm/page/rugbyatmethody|title=MCB Rugby at Methody contains picture of original and current Shield|accessdate=2007-04-26 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070322141040/http://methody.biznetservers.com/dsp_sub.cfm/page/rugbyatmethody <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-03-22}}</ref>
==Venue of finals==
All finals since 1973 have been played at [[Ravenhill Stadium|Ravenhill]]. Prior to that date, the most commonly used venues were the [[North of Ireland RFC|North of Ireland]] grounds on the [[Ormeau Road]] in [[Belfast]] and the former [[Royal Belfast Academical Institution]] grounds at Orangefield, Belfast.
==Future international players==
Over the years a selection of players who went on to win international caps appeared in the Medallion Shield final. One future international appeared in the first ever final in 1910 with James B O'Neill a member of the victorious Methodist College team.<ref name=Shield1910 /> He would win one cap for Ireland in 1920.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnscrum.com/ireland/rugby/player/2649.html|title=James O'Neill - Ireland|publisher=ESPN Scrum|accessdate=28 April 2011}}</ref>
Further examples of future international players include:
* [[Arthur Douglas|Arthur Coates Douglas]] played for [[Royal Belfast Academical Institution]] in the 1917 final, won 5 caps for Ireland.<ref name=Shield1917>{{cite news|title=Schools "Medallion" Competition|page=2|date=2 April 1917|newspaper=Belfast Newsletter}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnscrum.com/ireland/rugby/player/2992.html|title=Arthur Douglas - Ireland|publisher=ESPN Scrum|accessdate=28 April 2011}}</ref> * [[Richard Milliken|Dick Milliken]] captained the [[Bangor Grammar School]] team to victory in 1966 appeared 14 times for Ireland and 4 British & Irish Lion appearances. * [[Niall Malone]] played for [[Methodist College Belfast]] in the 1986 final, won 3 caps for Ireland. * [[Jonathan Bell (rugby player)|Jonathan Bell]] played for [[Coleraine Academical Institution]] in the 1989 final, won 36 caps for Ireland. * David Irwin played for Royal Belfast Academical Institute in the 1974 final, and was capped 25 times for Ireland and toured with the British Lions in 1983.
==Format==
Until 2004 the Medallion Shield was competed for through an open draw, and since then a seeding system has been employed to determine the point at which a school enters the competition.<ref name=Shield05>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/irish/4205429.stm|title=Medallion Shield|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 May 2007|date=25 January 2005}}</ref>
A Medallion Plate competition for first round losers was introduced in 1986.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}}
The competition took on a new format in 2005 with further minor changes made since.<ref name=Shield05 /> Each team is assigned to a seeding group which determines the stage at which that team joins the competition. Each stage is run on a single tie knock-out basis, with replays for drawn games when necessary.
The structure since the 2009-10 season is as follows:
*Stage 1. Weakest twelve teams enter for round 1. If necessary, a preliminary round will be played to establish these twelve teams. The six winners progress to round 2. The losers enter the Medallion Trophy together with the losers of the round 2 fixtures. The matches are determined by an open draw.
*Stage 2. A further ten teams enter together with the six winners from round 1. The matches in round 2 are determined by an open draw. The eight winners progress to round 3. The eight losers join the six losers from round 1 and any preliminary round losers and compete for the Medallion Trophy.
*Stage 3. A further eight teams enter together with the eight winners from round 2. The matches in round 3 are determined by an open draw. The eight winners progress to round 4. The eight losers contest for the Medallion Bowl.
*Stage 4. The top eight seeded teams join the remaining eight winners from round 3. The matches in round 4 are determined by an open draw. The winners proceed to the quarter finals, semi finals and final. The eight losers in round 4 play for the Medallion Plate.
In 2011-12 the top eight seeded teams are [[Ballymena Academy]], [[Campbell College]], [[Coleraine Academical Institution]], [[Methodist College Belfast]], [[Royal Belfast Academical Institution]], [[Sullivan Upper School]], [[The Royal School, Armagh]] and [[Wallace High School (Northern Ireland)|Wallace High School]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulsterrugby.com/branch/schools/9874.php|title=Northern Bank Medallion Shield Round 1 Draw|publisher=Ulster Rugby|date=30 November 2011|accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref>
==2010-11 season==
The [[2011 Medallion Shield]] saw [[Sullivan Upper School]], a team coached by former Ireland player and Scotland coach [[Willie Anderson (rugby player)|Willie Anderson]], defeat first time finalists [[Limavady Grammar School]] in the Shield final.<ref name=Shield11>{{cite web|url=http://www.londonderrysentinel.co.uk/sport/other-local-sport/heartache_for_teenagers_1_2527690|title=Heartache for teenagers|publisher=Londonderry Sentinel|date=23 March 2011|accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> [[Methodist College Belfast]] beat [[Ballymena Academy]] in the Plate, [[Rainey Endowed School]] beat [[Grosvenor Grammar School]] in the Bowl final and [[Dalriada School]] defeated [[Foyle and Londonderry College]] in the Trophy final.<ref name=Plate2011>{{cite web|url=http://www.ulsterrugby.com/branch/schools/9199.php|title=Northern Bank School Final Results from the Weekend |publisher=Ulster Rugby|date=28 March 2011|accessdate=13 April 2011}}</ref><ref name=Bowl11>{{cite web|url=http://magherafelt.northernconstitution.co.uk/articles/sports/20068/rainey-claim-northern-bank-medallion-bowl/|title=Rainey claim Northern Bank Medallion Bowl|publisher=Northern Constitution|date=30 March 2011|accessdate=30 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=Trophy11>{{cite web|url=http://ballymoney.thechronicle.uk.com/articles/sports/20026/dalriada-champions/|title=Dalriada champions!|publisher=Ballymoney Chronicle|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref>
